predicted_summary: Directs the Secretary of Transportation, acting through the Maritime Administration, to award a gold medal to the U.S. merchant marine personnel who, during their service, were integral in providing combat equipment, fuel, food, commodities, and raw materials to troops stationed overseas.Directs the President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives to make appropriate arrangements for the presentation, on behalf of the Government of the United States, of a gold medal to the U.S. Merchant Marine Corps in recognition of its service during World War II, particularly its role in ensuring the efficient and reliable transoceanic transport of military equipment and personnel despite consistent and ongoing exposure to enemy combatants from both air and the sea.TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: American Merchant Marine <n> Tile II: Women's Merchant Marine; <n>Title I: Americans Merchant Marine<n> - Directs the Secretary of the department in which the merchant marine is operating to issue regulations governing all operations of U.S. merchant marine vessels during World War II, including those in support of contingency operations. <n>Requires all merchant marine officers and men serving in contingency operations to be granted a leave of absence from duty during such period of service to enable them to perform their duties.The congressional gold medal is an appropriate way to shed further light on the service of the merchant marine in world war ii and the instrumental role they played in winning world war II.(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 22, 2008. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Authorizes the Department of the Treasury to strike and sell duplicates in bronze of the gold medal struck under this Act at a price sufficient to cover the costs of the medals, including labor, materials, dies, use of machinery, and overhead expenses.
summary_generated: . Merchant Marine of World War II Congressional Gold Medal Act (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to award a Congressional Gold Medal to the U.S. Merchant Marine in honor of their dedicated and vital service during World War II. (Sec. 4) The medal shall be given to the American Merchant Marine Museum for display.

predicted_summary: Instructs the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to propose to adopt regulations to provide that a covered investment fund research report that is published or distributed by a broker or dealer shall be deemed to be: (1) published by a Broker or dealer; and (2) distributed by an broker or dealers, without regard as to whether or not the research is disseminated by the broker or Dealer.Declares that the implementation of a safe harbor for covered investment funds is in the public interest and consistent with the purposes and duties of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), as well as any self-regulatory organization.The minimum float provision of a self-regulatory organization may not be imposed for any period exceeding the period of time referenced in specified federal regulations, or to prohibit the ability of a member to participate in a registered offering or other distribution of securities of a covered investment fund solely because the member has published or distributed a covered Investment Fund research report about such covered Investment fund or its securities.The application of the antifraud or antimanipulation provisions of the federal securities laws and rules adopted thereunder to a covered investment fund research report is limited to the extent that it is otherwise not subject to the content standards in the rules of any self-regulatory organization related to research reports, including those contained in the Rules governing communications with the public regarding investment companies or substantially similar standards.(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 12, 2009. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>(Sec. 3) Amends the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, respectively, to grant the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) regulatory authority over securities dealers and investment funds, including the authority to prohibit the sale or delivery of any security if the SEC finds that the transaction constitutes an unfair or deceptive act or practice.<n><n>Prescribes guidelines under which the SEC may: (1) refer an alleged violation to another entity; (2) prohibit the SEC from taking an enforcement action unless it first provides the entity with a reasonable opportunity to submit written notice of the violation; and (3) permit the SEC to assess and collect fees from violators of its rules, without regard to whether such violations were committed knowingly or willfully.Directs the Securities and Exchange Commission to deem to be a security listed on a national securities exchange, and not subject to specified laws of the investment company Act of 1940, any security that is listed on such exchange and that is not, according to the Act, subject to mandatory registration as a security by an investment company under such Act.The dealer about a covered investment fund or any securities issued by the covered investment Fund, but does not include a research report to the extent that the research report is published or distributed by thecovered investment fund, or any affiliate, of the covered Investment Fund.Securities Act of 1933 - Amends the securities act of 1933 to replace references to "research report" with references to the term "self-regulatory organization," except that such term shall not include an oral communication.
summary_generated: . Fair Access to Investment Research Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to establish and implement a safe harbor" for certain investment fund research reports published by brokers and dealers. Such reports shall be deemed not to be "offers" under specified provisions of securities law, even if the broker or dealer participates in the registered offering of the investment fund\\'s securities. In implementing the safe harbor, the SEC must prohibit a self-regulatory organization from maintaining or enforcing a rule that would prevent a member from: (1) publishing or distributing a covered investment fund research report solely because the member is also participating in a registered offering or other distribution of the fund\\'s securities, or (2) participating in a registered offering or other distribution of the fund solely because the member has published a research report about it. The bill restricts the SEC from conditioning the safe harbor upon specified requirements."

predicted_summary: The excellence in economic education credit for a taxable year is 50 percent of the amount paid or incurred during the taxable year to carry out specified purposes under the elementary and secondary education Act of 1965.Directs the Secretary of Commerce to determine which for profit organizations are allowed the credit for a taxable year in such manner as the Secretary determines appropriate.<n>Prohibits the award of the credit to: (1) a socially and economically disadvantaged small business concern; or (2) a small business Concern owned and controlled by women.Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to give tax priority to taxpayers that have qualified programs which serve either urban or rural underserved areas and to small businesses that are either owned by veterans or do not have more than $60 billion in assets.Defines a "qualified program" as a program in writing under which an eligible for profit organization awards one or more grants for the purpose of carrying out the objectives of promoting economic and financial literacy.Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to use the same method used by the board of governors of the federal reserve system to determine a bank holding company's consolidated assets under the financial stability Act of 2010, as well as other deductions or credits.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax deduction for contributions of excellence in economic education. (Sec. 45s.) Allows a general business credit for any qualified economic education expenses incurred by a taxpayer during the year.
summary_generated: Promoting Financial Literacy and Economic Opportunity Act of 2015 Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a business-related tax credit for 50% of the amount paid or incurred for the promotion of economic and financial literacy by eligible for profit organizations pursuant to a qualified program. Defines "eligible for profit organization" as a organization that: (1) has a qualified program in effect for the taxable year, and (2) has been determined by the Secretary of the Treasury to be an organization to whom the credit is allowed.

predicted_summary: Amends the developmental disabilities assistance and bill of rights Act to state congressional findings and policy regarding individuals with developmental disabilities, their families, and service providers: (1) in determining the appropriate level of assistance and services, including whether they should be provided free of charge; (2) in the selection of providers; (3) in the application of evaluations and procedures; and (4) in the provision of benefits and services.Individuals with developmental disabilities continually encounter various forms of discrimination in critical areas; "(4) individuals with developmental Disabilities frequently have severe disabilities that are likely to continue indefinitely; and (5) individuals with Developmental Disabilities Access, Inc., a national nonprofit organization dedicated to improving access, quality, and services for individuals with development disabilities, reports to the Congress on actions needed to improve access, including addressing discrimination and the effectiveness of community-based support services.The purpose of this act is to assure that individuals with developmental disabilities and their families have access to culturally competent services, supports, and other assistance and opportunities that promote independence, productivity, and integration and inclusion into the community.Declares U.S. policy that all programs, projects, and activities receiving assistance under this Act shall be carried out in a manner consistent with the principles that: (1) individuals with developmental disabilities, including those with the most severe disabilities, are capable of achieving independence, productivity, and integration and inclusion into the community; and (2) the provision of services, supports, and other assistance can improve such individuals' ability to achieve independence, Productivity, and Integration and inclusion.developmental disabilities assistance and bill of rights act provides assistance in an individualized manner, consistent with the unique strengths, resources, priorities, concerns, abilities, and capabilities of the individual.Directs the Secretary to: (1) provide advance public notice of any federal programmatic and administrative review and solicit public comment on the system funded under this part through such notice; and (2) include the findings of the public comment solicitation notice in the onsite visit report.Authorizes appropriations for FY 1994 through 1996 for grants under the act, as well as sums necessary for each of FY 1995 through 1996. (Current law authorizes appropriations through FY 1996.) <n>Amends the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act to prohibit State or local government entities from using more than a specified percentage of funds authorized under the Act to provide assistance or services to individuals with developmental disabilities in connection with any program or activity carried out by the Department of Health and Human Services.Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 and the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to increase the discretionary spending limits for FY 1994 and 1995.)
summary_generated: Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act Amendments of 1993 - Amends the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act to replace title I with part A: Provisions for Individuals With Developmental Disabilities; and part A with findings and policy. Declares U.S. policy with respect to State Developmental Disabilities Councils, protection and advocacy systems, university-affiliated programs, and other nationally significant activities.

predicted_summary: methyl-mercury is a toxic element that may cause neurological damage and other health-related problems as a result of fish or seafood consumption. methyl-MERcury are a persistent, bioaccumulative heavy metal that poses a significant risk to human health, wildlife, and the environment.Food and drug administration advises pregnant women and women of childbearing age not to eat shark, snapper, king snapper, red snapper, bluefish, catfish, bass, northern bass, saltwater walleye, and other finfish, including food and drug Administration advises other persons not toeat fish.Food and drug administration must provide guidance to the fishing industry to identify and prevent contaminated fish from reaching consumers.Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to impose a ban on the sale of any tuna or other fish to consumers if the Secretary determines that such fish has a mercury level exceeding one part per million parts per day.Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to work cooperatively with state fish and game officials to create an informative guide for distribution to the public about the dangers of the consumption of recreationally-caught fish. Requires the food and drug administration to resume its seafood methyl-mercury monitoring program to better document mercury levels in various fish species sold in commerce.Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to design and implement a national public education program regarding the presence of methyl-mercury in seafood and fish consumption advisories for methyl-MERcury. Directsthe administrator of the environmental protection agency to annually prepare a report on the impacts of mercury on human health and the environment.a consumer's mercury advisory notice is distributed widely by the Secretary, at no cost, to health professionals, particularly medical offices that provide gynecological, obstetrical, or pediatric care, and to the extent practicable shall be made available and posted in the patient or client areas of all maternal and child health and nutrition program offices.Fishing and Wildlife Conservation Act of 1994 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to issue regulations governing fishing and wildlife conservation. Sets forth provisions governing: (1) the promulgation of rules and regulations; (2) regulation of exports and imports; (3) pricing; (4) reporting requirements; (5) compensation; (6) health advisories; (7) research; and (8) funding.advisories and notices shall include information: (1) on limiting the consumption of certain high level fish and seafood to the general population and, for sensitive populations such as women of childbearing age and children, stress the importance of limiting consumption of frequently consumed fish that may exceed the environmental protection agency's reference dose; and (2) related to mercury fish tissue test results and fish consumption advisories for methyl-mercury.The Secretary of Health and Human Services shall make copies of an advisory on mercury ingestion from the consumption of fish and seafood available to state boards of health or other state and local governmental entities that have the same authority as a state board of health for distribution to the public and to local retail food establishments and restaurants.Directs the Secretary to: (1) design and implement a national public education program regarding the presence of methyl-mercury in seafood; (2) provide information to health professionals to improve the diagnosis and treatment of mercury-related illness and advise individuals whose health conditions place those individuals at particular risk; and (3) provide such information to State health professionals.Directs the Secretary to finalize the hazard analysis and critical control point assessment to determine whether or not methyl-mercury exposure through fish consumption is a public health hazard.The administrator shall distribute amounts made available equitably among the states through programs in existence on the date of enactment of this Act.(Sec. 2) Authorizes appropriations to: (1) carry out sampling; and (2) support the efforts of states to sample noncommercial fish and inland waterways for mercury and to produce state-specific health advisories related to mercury.
summary_generated: Mercury Health Advisory Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to promulgate a final rule establishing an advisory level for methylmercury that is equal to, or greater than, the action level limit established by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. Requires the advisory level to: (1) be based on testing conducted since 1993 by the Food and Drug Administration; and (2) warn women of childbearing age, nursing mothers, and young children about the potential adverse effects of methylmercury exposure from the consumption of specified fish.Directs the Secretary to work with other Federal agencies to achieve this goal.Requires the Administrator to contract with the National Research Council for technical review of the advisories.
